passages.text: August 29, 2025 12:15 PM GMT
The Week Ahead - Europe | Europe
Diversified Financials
Technology - Payments

Morgan Stanley does and seeks to do business with companies covered in Morgan Stanley Research. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of Morgan Stanley Research. Investors should consider Morgan Stanley Research as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
For analyst certification and other important disclosures, refer to the Disclosure Section, located at the end of this report.

\(+ =\) Analysts employed by non- U.S. affiliates are not registered with FINRA, may not be associated persons of the member and may not be subject to FINRA restrictions on communications with a subject company, public appearances and trading securities held by a research analyst account.

Morgan Stanley & Co. International plc+

1Q26 (May- July): We expect group rental revenue growth of \(c.2\%\) at the midpoint of management's FY26 guidance of \(0.4\%\) and in line with the May exit rate of \(+2\%\) in North America given at the FY in June. US Specialty should continue to outperform at MSD% YoY rental growth, while US General Tool is likely to continue growing at LSD%, with continued solid growth from mega- projects, and persistent weakness in local construction markets. We expect an upward revision to FY26 FCF guidance, reflecting the recently reinstated \(100\%\) bonus depreciation under the OBBBA (note, peer United Rentals raised its FCF guidance in July on the same basis - see Angel Castillo's note here). Company- compiled consensus for 1Q stands at revenues of \(\) 2,779\(m, EBITDA of\) \ \(1,289m\) , implying a margin of \(46.4\%\) and adj PBT of \(\) 557m\$

FY26 guidance: For FY26 (financial year- end April), Ashtead guides for a group rental revenue growth of \(0.4\%\) , which assumes fairly modest rate growth and no inflection in local non- residential construction markets. Management pointed out at the FY25 results that supply- demand dynamics were improving in the market, which should support rates. Gross capex guide is set at \(\) 1.8- 2.2bn\((including slightly lower gains on disposal at\) \ \(475m\) ), leading to a buoyant FCF guidance of \(\) 2- 2.3bn\(. Overall, this guidance implies PBT broadly flat YoY at just over\) \ \(2.1bn\) , assuming depreciation of \(c. \S 2.5bn\) and interest at \~ \(\) 535- 540m\(. Company- compiled consensus for FY26 stands at revenues of\) \ \(10,930m\) , EBITDA of \(\) 5,104m\(\) (46.7\%\(margin), EBITA of\) \ \(2,683m\) (24.5\% margin), adj PBT of \(\) 2,147m\(and diluted adj. EPS of\) 376c.

Stay Overweight: We view Ashtead as a structural long- term growth play, a market leader in a consolidation story. We think an outsized share of mega- projects and an increasing shift toward rental vs owned equipment should see continued market share gains. Additionally, increased exposure to non- construction/specialty/MRO provides increasing protection from a cyclical downturn. While near- term growth is likely to be held back by ongoing uncertainty in US construction markets alongside high interest rates, we believe we are past the trough of the downgrade cycle and consensus looks well calibrated from here. Ashtead's Sunbelt 4.0 roadmap to 2029 targets a 5- year organic rental revenue CAGR of \(6 - 9\%\) for the US/Group, with volume growth from greenfields and same- store alongside rate progression driving a \(\sim 10\%\) EPS CAGR to 2029.
1Q26 results at 7am UKt on Wednesday 3rd September. Analyst conference call at 11.30am UKt, dial in +44 (0) 33 0551 0200 with passcode: Ashtead Group Q1.
Exhibit 2: Ashtead 1Q26 and FY26-27 MSe vs. consensus
Source: Company data, Morgan Stanley Research estimates (e), Company-compiled consensus; YoY = year on year
**Ashmore Group plc** - MSe (£m) 2H25: Net revenue 68.1; EBITDA 25.5
**CVC Capital Partners plc** - MSe (€m) 1H25: Management fees 704; MFE 389; PFE
**Partners Group** - MSe (CHF m) 1H25: Management fees 859; Performance fees 257;
ASHM.L reports 2H25 earnings on Friday 5 September 2025

Ashmore reported AuM in line with expectations at $47.6bn (14th July statement) with net flows improving QoQ primarily due to a significant reduction in redemptions. As a result we are broadly in line with consensus on revenues at £68.1m for 2H FY25 vs. Cons at £69.1m with revenue margins at ~35bps for the full year, down 1bps YoY. We expect costs at £42.6m, slightly better than consensus expectations which translates into EBITDA ~6% above Consensus at £25.5m. We expect focus on commentary on the outlook and investor demand for EM, fee margin sustainability and cost growth expectations.
Exhibit 13: Ashmore 2H25 earnings statement
Source: Company data, Morgan Stanley Research estimates (e); H/H = half on half, Y/Y = year on year
Morgan Stanley & Co. International plc+
CVC.AS reports 1H2025 earnings on Thursday 4 September 2025

1H25 AuM was announced (14th August Activity Update) and reflected a decline in AuM YTD from €14.7bn to €14.0bn largely as a function of FX headwinds with fund raising broadly offset by step- downs and exit activity. However we expect that the YoY growth in the P&L will reflect the activation of flagship Europe/Americas IX mid- 2024 with management fees up >50% YoY in 1H25. Our estimates for revenues and EBITDA are close to Visible Alpha consensus, with carry fees expected to remain subdued though we anticipate the message for full year Performance Related Earnings (PRE) to show material growth vs 2024 to be reiterated. We expect focus on outlook commentary on capital markets activity following a relatively upbeat message on fund raising momentum in the 1H25 activity update.

Morgan Stanley & Co. International plc+
PGHN.S reports 1H25 earnings on Tuesday 2 September 2025

1H25 AuM was announced (15th July) and reflected solid progress in USD terms +15% YTD growth boosted by FX benefits and robust \$12.2bn gross fund raising. However CHF based P&L progress we expect will be more muted given FX headwinds (a higher proportion of USD and EUR revenues vs CHF costs) and in view of a sales mix which has skewed to

private credit (~45% of 1H25 fund raising vs ~20% of AuM at end 2024). We expect ~5% YoY growth in management fee revenues as a result with fee margins expected to decline modestly YoY (12bbps vs 126bps 1H24). Our estimates for revenues are broadly in line (~1% below) with consensus for management fees, and in-line with company consensus at an EBITDA level.
Exhibit 5: Partners 1H25 earnings statement
Source: Company data, Morgan Stanley Research estimates (e), Visible Alpha consensus as of 28th Aug 2025; H/H = half on half, Y/Y = year on year
Biomerieux SA - MSe (€mn) 2Q25: Group sales 971 with organic growth 7.6%; Adj EBIT 345 with margins 16.7%
(BIOX.PA, Equal- weight)
Morgan Stanley & Co. International plc+
We see downside risks to 2025 numbers that could lower the chances of a guidance raise by BIM at its upcoming 1H25 result on 4 Sept.

1) Non-respiratory slowdown: BIM's non-respiratory (non-RP) BIOFIRE sales has seen a deceleration in growth in the past 4 consecutive quarters from 19% in Q2'24 to 11% in Q1'25. Its main competitor Cepheid saw low-double-digit % growth in non-respiratory Cepheid sales in Q2, a slowdown vs mid-teens in the prior 4 quarters. In the event of a further slowdown, this would introduce some downside risk to BIM's FY guidance of >10% growth in non-RP BIOFIRE sales.

2) Respiratory upside lower: Lower flu cases in Australia, recent US CDC data and weaker Respiratory prints at Cepheid (-52% Resp sales growth Q2 vs Q1) lowers the likelihood of significant upside to 2025 BIOFIRE respiratory panel (RP) sales.

3) China market weakness to pressure Microbiology/Immuno: Key Diagnostics peers ABT/ROG/DHR cited China headwinds namely VBP (volume-based procurement), DRG (Diagnosis Related Group) unbundling policies and healthcare reimbursement changes as the main downward drivers of their Diagnostics results in 2Q (see EU Diagnostics: Read-across from Peer Reporting). The magnitude of the China drag implies it was down between -20% to -50% in the quarter, i.e. a considerable headwind. Applying the midpoint of this decline to our Microbiology/Immunoassay estimates for BIM would yield organic growth of +4%/-10% for Q2, which would be ~200bps below VA consensus. In other words, we estimate China headwinds would amount to ~€20m downside to sales in the quarter, which we think is not baked into consensus.

4) FX headwinds drive some downside: On current rates we estimate FX is closer to a 4ppt headwind to group sales in 2025 (vs 2ppts prior), driven largely by a weaker USD to which >40% of BIM's group sales are exposed. While the company does hedge its currency exposure, we note that currency depreciation still led to BIM raising its EBIT FX headwind guidance in the 1Q'25 result to "€35 - €40m" from €30m prior. Our EBIT forecast embeds €50m of FX headwind, resulting in €694m for FY25, -3% vs cons €719m.
Exhibit 6: BioMerieux
Source: Visible Alpha, Morgan Stanley Research estimates

Eurowag - MSe (€mn) 1H25: Revenue 155.3; Adj EBITDA 64.7
Morgan Stanley & Co. International plc+

We are broadly in line with consensus: For 1H25 we forecast total net revenue of €155m, up c. \(9.5\%\) y/y on an organic basis, which is \(1\%\) below consensus. For the full year, we forecast c. \(10\%\) organic growth, which is in- line with consensus and consistent with the company's FY25 guidance for low- double digit net revenue growth. As is typical for Eurowag, we expect the year to be more 2H weighted, with the 1H/2H total revenue split \(48\% /52\%\) on our forecasts. Below the line, we expect adj. EBITDA to also be more weighted to 2H and thus expect 1H25 adj. EBITDA of c. €65m (representing a margin of c. \(41.7\%\) ). This is c. \(2\%\) below Visible Alpha consensus in 1H; however we note that most estimates do not formally break out a 1H/2H split, and given the usual 2H weighting, we think buy- side expectations to be closer to our estimates. Our FY25 margin of \(41.7\%\) is broadly in- line with consensus ( \(41.8\%\) ). We are neutral into results.
Eurowag will report 1H25 results on Thursday 4th September.

(VLTSA.PA, Equal- weight)
Morgan Stanley & Co. International plc+

We think Voltalia's 1H25 results and CMD on 4th September will be a neutral to small negative event for the name. We see a risk of small consensus EBITDA downgrades for 2025. For the CMD, we expect a message of increased discipline and focus and think the group's 2027 EBITDA may be cut (although this seems already well anticipated by consensus).

For the CMD, we expect a message of increased discipline and focus. While it is too early to know the nature and the magnitude of Voltalia's transformation plan, we believe one of the key areas that could be addressed is the group's low EBITDA margins on the Services activities (excluding Development). We think that cost saving initiatives and a refocus on the most profitable activities could be at the core of the new plan envisaged by the group. We also believe that the group's significant exposure to Brazilian wind & solar - especially in Rio Grande do Norte (for which market fundamentals have been tough) could also be a key topic - we note the group has already been diversifying towards new emerging and less mature markets (Uzbekistan, Tunisia, Egypt,...) with lower curtailment risk. Last but not least, we think Voltalia's financial leverage is currently high (although we understand it was expected that leverage would peak in 2024- 25) and we could thus envisage a more disciplined investment trajectory as well as potential disposals for the group going forward.

We believe the group may have to lower its current 2027 normalised EBITDA target of €475mn at its CMD given: 1) weaker BRL, 2) risk of prolonged wind and solar curtailment in Brazil (although any regulatory change on potential compensation could change that), 3) potential perimeter changes implied by the group's new strategy. We believe a new 2027 EBITDA target of €400- 450mn would be more realistic. We note that consensus is already within this range at €416mn and we thus do not expect material earnings downgrades from here.

Potential risk of small EBITDA downgrades? While Voltalia has not communicated a 2025 EBITDA target yet, higher than expected curtailment (even though the 5.2 TWh objective is still valid), together with weak BRL and the recent incident at the Cacao power plant (which could represent a potential loss of around €6mn in turnover in 2025 according to the company) may imply some small downside to consensus EBITDA estimates (€245mn in Visible Alpha) in our view.

For 1H25 results themselves, we expect Voltalia to deliver 1H25 EBITDA of €91mn and 1H25 net income of €16mn. This implies a flat net income YoY given the growth at EBITDA level (22% YoY on our estimates) should be entirely offset by more negative financial result in our view (as a result of rising debt). We see EBITDA delivery in the year very much back end loaded, with significantly higher power volumes expected in 2H25 and potentially higher contribution from the Services division.
Voltalia reports its 1H25 results on September, 4th.

Morgan Stanley uses a relative rating system using terms such as Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated or Underweight (see definitions below). Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy, Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold and sell. Investors should carefully read the definitions of all ratings used in Morgan Stanley Research. In addition, since Morgan Stanley Research contains more complete information concerning the analyst's views, investors should carefully read Morgan Stanley Research, in its entirety, and not infer the contents from the rating alone. In any case, ratings (or research) should not be used or relied upon as investment advice. An investor's decision to buy or sell a stock should depend on individual circumstances (such as the investor's existing holdings) and other considerations.
(as of July 31, 2025)

The Stock Ratings described below apply to Morgan Stanley's Fundamental Equity Research and do not apply to Debt Research produced by the Firm. For disclosure purposes only (in accordance with FINRA requirements), we include the category headings of Buy, Hold, and Sell alongside our ratings of Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight. Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy, Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold, and sell but represent recommended relative weightings (see definitions below). To satisfy regulatory requirements, we correspond Overweight, our most positive stock rating, with a buy recommendation; we correspond Equal- weight and Not- Rated to hold and Underweight to sell recommendations, respectively.

Data include common stock and ADRs currently assigned ratings. Investment Banking Clients are companies from whom Morgan Stanley received investment banking compensation in the last 12 months. Due to rounding off of decimals, the percentages provided in the % of total' column may not add up to exactly 100 percent.

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Equal-weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Not-Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In-Line (I): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia -relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub-regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
